Award.AwardTitle: PEET: Taxonomic Expertise in True Bugs: Systematic and Monographic Research on Assassin Bugs (Heteroptera: Reduviidae)
Award.AbstractNarration:
The assassin bugs (Reduviidae) are charismatic members of the order Heteroptera or "true bugs." There are many species of assassin bugs, and they exhibit remarkable diversity, not only in the way they look but also in their behavior. Many assassin bugs are beneficial because they eat potentially harmful insects. However, some species feed on vertebrate blood and carry Chagas disease, which affects millions of people in South and Central America. Unfortunately, we do not know how many species of assassin bugs exist, nor do we have good ways to identify them. Very few taxonomists study assassin bugs, which makes it hard to know much about their evolution, behavior, or even where they all live. This project will assemble an international team of scientists to train students in the evolution and classification of insects, with a special focus on the assassin bugs. The research will combine fieldwork and studies of museum specimens with powerful descriptive and analytical approaches as well as development and use of bioinformatics tools, while focusing on five subgroups of the assassin bugs.

Biodiversity information on an ecologically extraordinary group of insects will become available while advancing knowledge on species that are of medical importance and of interest as natural enemies. At least five graduate level trainees and five undergraduate students will be trained in systematics of Reduviidae and the true bugs. Monographs, online tools including identification keys, an electronic catalog and a digital library of taxonomic literature, images of type specimens, species pages, and movies documenting assassin bug behavior will make the group accessible to educators, ecologists, those dealing with integrated pest control, and the general public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has focused on advancing knowledge of the Reduviidae or assassin bugs, one of the largest families of insects in the order Hemiptera (6,801 described spp. in 25 subfamilies). The great majority of species feed on other insects, but members of one subfamily are specialized vertebrate blood-feeders and are known as kissing bugs. Assassin bugs comprise beneficial predators of pest insects, but some species potentially harm pollinators including wild bees. Kissing bugs are the sole vectors of a unicellular organism that causes Chagas disease in humans and are the economically most damaging group of true bugs. Assassin bugs display exciting prey specializations (e.g., on millipedes, termites, or spiders) and catch their prey using a wealth of specialized methods that include sticky traps and fishing techniques. Sound knowledge of species-level diversity and phylogenetic relationships are important to understand how these strategies have evolved, giving rise to one of the most diverse groups of predators among animals. However, the biodiversity of assassin bugs has remained poorly documented because of a lack of modern experts and phylogenetic relationships within the group are largely unknown.

The Reduviid PEET project has tackled large taxonomic revisions, has generated the largest phylogeny of assassin bugs to date, and has explored the evolution of different subfamilies. A total of 314 species were revised during the taxonomic parts of the Reduviid PEET projects, including 134 species that were discovered and described as new to science. A well-illustrated identification key to assassin bug subfamilies was published that now makes this group much more accessible to the non-specialist. Using various methods, the project has gained insights into the evolution of several subgroups including the charismatic sticky trap bugs, millipede assassin bugs, and termite assassin bugs. Thirty-three papers and book chapters are published or in press and one is submitted. Lab members have given 55 Reduviid PEET-related presentations at scientific meetings.

Training the next generation of insect systematists was a key aspect of this grant. Five PhD students, one MSc student, and four visiting international students were trained at the University of California, Riverside. Nineteen undergraduate students (eleven female, four Hispanic) were involved in independent research, five presented at conferences, and the results of five undergraduate projects are published. Three postdocs were involved in student mentoring. Postdocs and graduate students that were trained on this project now hold faculty, museum researcher, or postdoc positions in the field of systematic entomology. As part of the project, >42,000 specimens were databased and >2,000 imaged. Images, distribution maps, and specimen records are publicly available (e.g., http://research.amnh.org/pbi/heteropteraspeciespage). Two reduviid workshops attracted >30 participants. Team members conducted 25 weeks of fieldwork and spent 22 weeks curating specimens in various natural history collections. All participants engaged in public outreach.
